project.name: Deep Ocean Lab
project.tagline: Ocean Zone Educational Explorer for Kids
project.subject: Marine Biology / Ocean Science
features: Depth gauge that descends with progress
Animated ocean canvas with bioluminescent particles
Sonar sweep visual on quiz screen
O2 bar and submarine icon tracking
Fun facts unlocked after each zone

questions.q: The Sunlight Zone is the most productive ocean layer. Why?
questions.explain: Phytoplankton in the Sunlight Zone photosynthesize, producing over 50% of Earth's oxygen â€” more than all rainforests combined!

questions.q: Coral reefs are found in the Sunlight Zone. What percentage of ocean species live there?
questions.explain: Though coral reefs cover less than 1% of the ocean floor, they support about 25% of all marine species â€” ocean biodiversity hotspots!

questions.q: Why are most fish in the Sunlight Zone colorful?
options: Colors are used for camouflage, communication, and mating
questions.explain: Fish use color to blend in, warn predators they're toxic, attract mates, and communicate â€” it's their language!

questions.q: The Great Barrier Reef is the world's largest coral reef. Where is it?
questions.explain: The Great Barrier Reef off Australia is so large it can be seen from space â€” stretching over 2,300 km!

facts.text: The Sunlight Zone (0â€“200m) gets enough light for photosynthesis. It produces over half of Earth's oxygen.
Clownfish live within the stinging tentacles of sea anemones â€” they're immune to the sting and help each other survive.
Great white sharks can detect one drop of blood in 100 liters of water from up to 5km away.
Dolphins use echolocation â€” clicking sounds that bounce off objects â€” to navigate and hunt even in murky water.

questions.q: The Twilight Zone gets very little light. How do creatures here survive the darkness?
options: Many use bioluminescence to produce their own light
questions.explain: About 90% of deep sea creatures are bioluminescent â€” they produce their own chemical light for hunting, hiding, and mating!

questions.q: What is the Diel Vertical Migration â€” one of the largest animal migrations on Earth?
options: Millions of sea creatures rising at night to feed near the surface, then sinking at dawn
questions.explain: Every night, trillions of animals migrate from the deep up to the surface to feed, then descend again at dawn to avoid predators.

questions.q: The giant squid lives in the Twilight Zone. How large can it grow?
questions.explain: Giant squids can reach 13 meters â€” as long as a double-decker bus! Their eyes are the biggest in the animal kingdom.

questions.q: What is 'marine snow' that falls through the Twilight Zone?
options: Tiny particles of dead organisms and waste drifting downward
questions.explain: 'Marine snow' is a constant shower of organic particles â€” dead plankton, feces, mucus â€” that feeds creatures in the deep. Yummy!

facts.text: 90% of deep-sea creatures produce bioluminescence â€” their own light using a chemical reaction involving luciferin.
The giant squid has eyes the size of footballs â€” the biggest eyes in the animal kingdom, evolved to spot faint light in the deep.
Marine snow falls at about 100 meters per day, carrying carbon from the surface to the deep ocean floor.
Octopuses can change color AND texture in less than a second to match any surface â€” even perfectly mimicking other animals.

questions.q: The Anglerfish uses a glowing lure to attract prey. Where does this light come from?
options: Bioluminescent bacteria living inside the lure
questions.explain: The anglerfish's lure contains symbiotic bioluminescent bacteria â€” tiny living organisms that glow as a built-in fishing light!

questions.q: At 1,000m depth, pressure is crushing. How does a sperm whale survive diving this deep?
options: Their ribcage can collapse and lungs compress without damage
questions.explain: Sperm whales have flexible ribcages that collapse under pressure, allowing their lungs to compress safely as they dive â€” incredible adaptation!

questions.q: The Midnight Zone has no sunlight at all. What do creatures here primarily eat?
options: Marine snow, each other, and migrating creatures from above
questions.explain: In total darkness, deep-sea creatures feast on marine snow drifting down, hunt each other, or ambush migrants passing through.

questions.q: How cold is the water in the Midnight Zone?
questions.explain: The deep ocean stays a near-constant 2â€“4Â°C â€” close to freezing but not quite, because salt water freezes at -1.8Â°C.

facts.text: Anglerfish females carry males fused onto their bodies permanently â€” the male merges and becomes a sperm-providing parasite.
Sperm whales can dive to 2,250m and hold their breath for 90 minutes â€” the deepest and longest dive of any mammal.
The barreleye fish has a transparent head and tubular eyes that rotate to look upward through its skull to spot prey silhouettes.
Pressure at 1,000m is 100 times that at the surface â€” enough to crush a submarine if it isn't specially designed.

questions.q: The Abyssal Zone covers most of the ocean floor. What percentage of the ocean floor is it?
questions.explain: The abyssal zone makes up about 83% of the entire ocean floor â€” it's the most common environment on Earth, yet we know very little about it!

questions.q: What are 'Polymetallic nodules' found scattered across the abyssal plain?
options: Rock-like lumps of iron, manganese and metals that grow 1cm per million years
questions.explain: These potato-sized nodules grow incredibly slowly â€” 1cm per million years â€” and are now being studied as sources of rare metals needed for batteries.

questions.q: The abyssal plain is flat. Why?
options: It was scraped flat by glaciers
Millions of years of sediment rain has covered all features
questions.explain: Billions of years of marine snow â€” dead organisms and particles â€” have filled in every bump and crater, creating one of the flattest surfaces on Earth.

questions.q: What percentage of the ocean have humans actually explored?
questions.explain: We have explored less than 20% of Earth's oceans. We know more about the surface of Mars than we do about our own ocean floor!

facts.text: The abyssal zone is in total darkness, near-freezing, and under 400â€“600 times atmospheric pressure.
The small but mighty Hirondellea gigas shrimp lives in the deepest ocean trenches and can survive pressure that would crush most machinery.
We have mapped more of the surface of Venus and Mars than our own ocean floor. The deep sea is our last true frontier.
Polymetallic nodules on the sea floor hold more cobalt and nickel than all land deposits combined â€” a future resource for clean energy tech.

questions.q: The Mariana Trench is the deepest point on Earth. How deep is Challenger Deep?
questions.explain: Challenger Deep in the Mariana Trench reaches 11,034m â€” if you put Mount Everest at the bottom, its peak would still be over a mile underwater!

questions.q: Who was the first person to reach the deepest point of the Mariana Trench solo?
questions.explain: Film director James Cameron made a solo dive to Challenger Deep in 2012 in a specially built submersible â€” the first solo dive to the bottom!

questions.q: Incredibly, life exists even in the Hadal Zone. What kind of organisms live there?
questions.explain: The hadal zone teems with life! Snailfish (the world's deepest fish), giant amphipod crustaceans, and unique bacteria thrive under crushing pressure.

questions.q: Hadal zone pressure is about 1,100 atmospheres. What happens to a wooden object sent there?
options: It is compressed to a tiny fraction of its size
questions.explain: Styrofoam cups sent to the Mariana Trench return the size of a thimble â€” compressed to almost nothing by the crushing pressure. Scientists do this to show kids!

facts.text: Challenger Deep is 11,034m â€” the full height of Mount Everest would fit inside with over 2km to spare.
The Mariana snailfish (Pseudoliparis swirei) is the deepest-known fish, living at 8,000m â€” it looks almost transparent.
Scientists found plastic bags and candy wrappers at the bottom of the Mariana Trench â€” human pollution has reached the deepest point on Earth.
James Cameron's sub for his 2012 solo dive was shaped like a giant torpedo and took 2.5 hours to sink to the bottom.

questions.q: Hydrothermal vents were only discovered in 1977. What was the shocking discovery?
options: Entire ecosystems based on CHEMISTRY not sunlight
questions.explain: Scientists found communities of creatures living without ANY sunlight â€” fueled by chemosynthesis (bacteria converting vent chemicals into energy). Life found a new way!

questions.q: How hot is the water shooting out of hydrothermal vents?
questions.explain: Vent water can reach 400Â°C â€” hot enough to melt lead! It stays liquid because of the crushing pressure at that depth (water boils at higher temperatures under pressure).

questions.q: Giant tube worms live at vents, up to 2m long. They have NO mouth, no gut, no stomach. How do they eat?
options: Billions of symbiotic bacteria inside them convert vent chemicals into food
questions.explain: Tube worms have no digestive system at all! Their entire body houses billions of chemosynthetic bacteria that convert hydrogen sulfide from the vents into food.

questions.q: Why are hydrothermal vents important for the origin of life theories?
options: They show life can exist without sunlight, suggesting life may have started in chemical-rich environments
questions.explain: Vent ecosystems suggest Earth's earliest life may have started in similar chemical-rich, sunlight-free environments â€” and informs the search for life on other planets!

facts.text: Hydrothermal vents emit water at up to 400Â°C â€” so hot it would normally be steam, but deep-sea pressure keeps it liquid.
Giant tube worms grow 2m long, have no mouth or stomach, and live off bacteria that eat poisonous hydrogen sulfide from the vents.
Yeti crabs at vents have hairy claws packed with bacteria that detoxify the toxic vent chemicals before the crab consumes them.
The discovery of vent life in 1977 rewrote biology â€” it proved life doesn't need sunlight, reshaping the search for life on other worlds.
